Fish are the principal source of protein for Sri Lanka’s population, and 
play  a  vital  role  in  meeting  basic  nutritional  and  livelihood  needs. 
Extensive water bodies constitute a potentially rich source of food and 
income  for  the  rural  population  living  in  their  proximity.  However,  in 
2000,  only  12%  of  the  country’s  fish  production  came  from  inland 
fisheries and aquaculture. The production potential of the freshwater 
and  brackish  water  resources  has  not  been  optimally  utilized  due  to 
several factors, including lack of (i) fish seed for stocking, (ii) trained 
extension  staff  and  outreach,  and  (iii)  medium-term  credit  to  finance 
increased production. 
 
An analysis of consumption trends shows a growing demand for fish 
in  both  rural  and  urban  markets.  Significant  opportunities  are  also 
emerging  for  sale  of  freshwater  fish  and  aquatic  products  beyond 
traditional  local  markets.  Both  community-based  and  private  sector 
initiatives  and  interest  exist  to  avail  of  these  opportunities,  given 
appropriate  support  to  invest  in  developing  inland  fisheries  and 
aquaculture production and marketing. 
 
The Project will promote market-driven and sustainable management 
of  inland  fisheries  and  aquaculture  through  resource  development 
and  quality  improvement.  It  will  initially  be  implemented  in  nine 
districts in six provinces in the dry zone. Model aquaculture and fish 
processing enterprises will be developed, which may be replicated in 
other  parts  of  the  country,  including  the  north  and  east,  where  the 
water resources exist.  

 iv 

 

 
The Project is organized in five parts: inland fisheries and aquaculture 
development,  fish  quality  improvement  and  marketing,  facilitation  of 
access to credit, institutional strengthening, and project management. 
The  successful  implementation  of  these  is  expected  to  result  in  the 
following  outcomes:  (i)  increased  production  of  freshwater  fish  and 
other  aquatic  products  for  the  rural,  urban,  and  export  markets;  (ii) 
improved  quality  and  increased  consumption  of  inland  fish;  (iii) 
improved access to credit for use in inland fisheries and aquaculture; 
and  (iv)  strengthened  capacity  of  NAQDA  and  other  sector 
institutions. Increased investment by small- and medium-scale private 
entrepreneurs  will  be  encouraged,  and  community-based  fisheries 
management will be strengthened. 
 
The  Project  is  estimated  to  cost  $30.0  million  equivalent,  of  which 
$8.6  million  is  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $21.4  million  equivalent  is

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed loans 
to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  Aquatic  Resource  Development  and 
Quality Improvement Project (Appendix 1). 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The  Sri  Lanka  fisheries  sector  has  three  production  subsectors:  (i)  coastal  fisheries;  (ii) 
offshore  fisheries;  and  (iii)  inland  fisheries,  including  aquaculture  in  both  freshwater  and  brackish 
water  areas.  Although  the  fisheries  sector  contributed  only  2.6–3.0%  annually  to  the  country’s 
gross national product during 1995–2000, it plays a vital role in meeting the basic nutritional and 
livelihood  needs  of  the  population.  Fish  are  the  principal  source  of  protein  for  the  country’s 
population, accounting for about 60% of the total animal protein intake, on average, and up to 85% 
in the rural areas. Annual per capita fish consumption, estimated at 15–16 kilograms (kg), is lower 
than the 21 kg recommended by the Sri Lanka Medical Research Institute. Over 360,000 tons (t) of 
fish are consumed annually in Sri Lanka, only 78% of which is from domestic production, the rest is 
supplied through imports, mainly in dried form. Nevertheless, the country’s balance of trade in fish 
and fish products is positive, with exports exceeding imports by about SLRs5 billion in 2000. 
 
3. 
In  2000,  official  estimates  of  total  fish  production  in  Sri  Lanka  were  304,380  t.  However, 
only about 12% (or 36,700 t) of this came from inland fisheries and aquaculture, while the rest was 
from  coastal  and  offshore  fisheries.  Production  of  the  inland  fisheries  and  aquaculture  subsector 
recovered from a low of 12,000 t in 1994 to the 2000 level in 6 years, although this is still below the 
highest annual production of 38,190 t achieved in 1990. The sharp fall in production from 1990 to 
1994 is attributed to the abrupt withdrawal of state assistance to the subsector in 1990, until it was 
resumed in 1994.  
 
4. 
Consumption  trends  from  1986–1997  show  a  growing  demand  for  both  freshwater  and 
marine fish, in urban and rural markets. Total demand for fish increased by 13% from 102,966 t to 
116,144 t, with demand for marine and freshwater fish increasing by 14% and 7%. Opportunities 
are  emerging  for  marketing  freshwater  fish  beyond  the  rural  areas  where  these  are  commonly 
produced  for  home  consumption.  Per  capita  consumption  of  freshwater  fish  in  urban  areas  has 
shown  an  increasing  trend,  despite  distribution  and  marketing  constraints  that  limit  movement  of 
the  commodity  from  the  reservoirs  to  markets  in  other  districts  where  freshwater  fish  is  in  short 
supply but in great demand (Appendix 2).  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

5. 
Extensive water bodies constitute a potentially rich source of food and income for the rural 
population living in their proximity. However, widespread poverty and protein scarcity persist due to 
lack  of  sustainable  development  and  management  of  these  water  bodies.  A  rapid  social 
assessment survey during project preparation1 found that a third of rural households living near the 
perennial  and  seasonal  tanks  fall  below  the  poverty  threshold.  Of  these,  more  than  60%  are 
involved,  on  a  full-  or  part-time  basis,  in  freshwater  fish  culture  and  earn  annual  household 
incomes  of  less  than  SLRs30,000.  Among  these  marginal  rural  communities,  the  consumption  of

of  urban  communities.  For  these  households,  the  food  bill  takes  up  more  than  half  their  small

bodies, particularly the minor reservoirs and seasonal tanks, has not been optimally utilized due to 
the  severe  shortage  of  freshwater  fish  seed  for  stocking—and  subsequent  harvesting—for  food

production and rearing technology to inland fishers as well as rural communities at large. 
 
7. 
A  regular  and  adequate  supply  of  production  inputs  is  needed:  (i)  fish  fingerlings  for 
stocking  in  tanks  and  growout  in  ponds,  and  (ii)  extension  support  and  credit  assistance  to 
communities  to  enable  them  to  manage  a  new  economic  activity.  This  will  require  establishing 
more  fish  hatcheries,  as  well  as  developing  mechanisms  for  effective  and  efficient  transfer  of 
technology  from  government  extension  centers  to  small  fishers  and  rural  communities  that  will 
eventually take the lead in producing fingerlings for rearing to market size. The formal and informal 
private  sector  can  play  a  key  role  in  bringing  about  increased  production  of  inland  fish  and  other 
aquatic  products  for  the  rural,  urban,  and  export  markets.  Adequate  social  preparation  and 
community organization of small fishers, as well as extension of appropriate technology to private 
entrepreneurs need time. Therefore, public sector institutions will initially need to be strengthened, 
to  enable  them  to  provide  technical  support  to  community-based  organizations  (CBOs)  and  the 
private sector for inland fish production, postharvest processing, and marketing. 
 
8. 
The National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) was established in 1999 as the 
lead government agency to develop and regulate inland fisheries and aquaculture in the country. 
NAQDA’s technical, financial, and project implementation capacities need to be strengthened, and 
the law governing its existence and operations amended, to enable it to fully exercise its mandate. 
Other agencies and entities involved in the subsector will also need to be strengthened, especially 
CBOs.2 Extensive social mobilization and training efforts are required to ensure active involvement 
and participation of CBOs in inland fisheries and aquaculture enterprises, as well as in community-
based  fisheries  management.  As  demand  grows,  awareness  among  stakeholders  of  the 
achievable  production  potential  of  these  water  bodies  will  have  to  be  developed,  and  their 
commitment to sustainable development and management of these resources secured. 
 
9. 
The  proposed  Project  will  promote  sustainable  development  of  inland  fisheries  and 
aquaculture. It will be the first major initiative in inland fisheries and aquaculture in Sri Lanka, after 
the completion of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed Aquaculture Development Project 
in 1991.3 Based on lessons learned from this and other projects, the Project will adopt a phased 
approach  using  demonstration  facilities  before  full-scale  implementation  of  identified  aquaculture 
enterprises (Appendix 3 provides details on recent external assistance to the sector). The Project 
will  also  promote  the  active  participation  of  CBOs  in  the  choice  of  assistance,  their  direct

12. 
The  Project  is  complementary  to  ongoing  ADB  loan-funded  projects  and  is  supportive  of 
government poverty reduction programs. Several government-funded and community-led initiatives 
are  currently  being  implemented  to  empower  the  poor  to  reenter  the  economic  mainstream.  In 
cooperation with NGOs and CBOs, the Government provides seed capital and matching grants to 
community-based  initiatives  aimed  at  helping  specific  target  groups  of  very  poor  communities. 
These  programs  include  microfinance  schemes  aimed  at  promoting  income-generating,  self-
employment enterprises for the rural poor, including in remote inland areas. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Objectives 

13.

B. 

Social Measures and Impact on Poverty 

53. 
Population in the Project Area. The total population in the nine districts of the project area 
is  6.1  million  in  1.5  million  households  with  an  average  household  size  of  4.4.  The  proportion  of 
females  (51.9%)  living  in  the  project  area  is  slightly  higher  than  that  of  males  (48.1%).  The 
population  consists  of  about  82.9%  Sinhalese,  12.3%  Tamils,  3.8%  Muslims,  and  less  than  1% 
other  groups.  Surveys  conducted  during  project  preparation  estimate  that  about  33%  of  the 
population in the project area live below the poverty line. 
 
54. 
Lack  of  Access  to  Services.  Some  22%  of  households  in  the  project  area  do  not  have 
latrines and only 58% have access to safe drinking water. About 30% of households are connected 
to  electricity.  Extension,  health,  and  other  services  are  limited.  However,  the  nine  districts  have 
sufficient schools and an adequate number of teachers. As small perennial and seasonal tanks are 
located  in  remote  and  sparsely  populated  areas,  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  higher  here  than 
around larger perennial tanks. The Project will define social selection criteria and adopt a phased 
approach, ensuring that small perennial and seasonal tanks are prioritized in project interventions. 

 16 

 

The  Project  will  also  improve  the  mobility  of  extension  staff,  enabling  them  to  reach  these 
disadvantaged areas. 
 
55. 
Social  Stratification.  A  small  group  of  poorest  of  the  poor  (about  1%  of  households 
targeted) gets its income from marginal employment as casual laborers, seasonal employment as 
farm  workers,  and  subsidies  from  the  Government.  To  supplement  their  diet,  these  people  are 
forced  to  engage  in  illegal  fishing.  The  Project  will  attempt  to  reach  this  group  through  targeted 
interventions, particularly provision of training in skills needed in fisheries (e.g., net mending) and 
by  supporting  the  use  of  their  newly  acquired  skills.  Specifically,  alternative  income  opportunities 
will  prevent  illegal  fishing  by  this  group.  The  groups  living  below  and  just  above  the  poverty  line 
(about  53%  of  the  target  population)  consist  of  full-time  and  part-time  fisherfolk,  bicycle  vendors, 
and  small-scale  animal  husbandry  operators.  A  large  number  of  respondents  from  these  groups 
expressed  the  need  for  more  job  opportunities.  They  will  be  provided  access  to  (i)  extension 
services,  (ii)  sources  of  fish  seed  and  fish  culture  information,  (iii)  credit,  and  (iv)  training  on  fish 
production  and  improved  fish  handling.  Existing  CBOs  will  be  strengthened  using  participatory 
approaches, starting with gender-sensitive participatory assessments of organizational capacities. 
Around  seasonal  and  minor  tanks,  new  groups  will  be  organized  by  NGOs.  All  training  will  be 
hands-on, participatory, and adapted to the needs of the respective target group (Appendix 9). 
 
56. 
Social Conflicts. Social conflicts have evolved, in particular, around some larger perennial 
tanks  in  the  south,  mainly  between  the  more  affluent  truck-owning  fish  vendors  and  organized 
fisherfolk. Ethnicity does not play a role in these conflicts. The project scope will not include tanks 
where such conflicts exist, until the conflicts have been resolved to the satisfaction of the PMO and 
the  parties  involved.  The  Project  will  facilitate  resolution  of  conflicts  by  providing  mediation  and 
negotiation  assistance  in  such  cases,  building  on  existing  systems  for  dispute  resolution.  More 
conflicts  may  arise  as  a  result  of  increased  utilization  of  seasonal  and  minor  perennial  tanks  for 
culture-based  fisheries.  Conflict  management  training  will  be  provided  to  CBOs,  extension  staff, 
and NGOs, enabling them to handle such problems at the local level. To minimize conflicts arising 
in  the  future,  a  thorough  situation  analysis  will  be  carried  out,  and  implications  of  planned 
interventions will be discussed with the target group population. 
 
57. 
Gender.  At  present  women  are  rarely  involved  in  aquaculture-related  activities  in  the 
project  area.  Consequently  their  participation  in  fishers’  associations  is  low.  But  they  have 
expressed  great  interest  in  increasing  their  involvement.  The  Project  will  encourage  women’s 
participation  and  provide  opportunities  for  them  to  play  active  roles  in  setting  up,  operating,  and 
managing small-scale culture-based fishery enterprises. The formation and strengthening of fishers’ 
associations  will  ensure  equitable  opportunities  for  (i)  membership  and  representation  of  women, 
and (ii) assuming leadership functions in these associations.  
 
58. 
NAQDA and other implementing agencies will take steps to ensure that women living in the 
project  area  participate  fully  in  planning  and  implementing  project  activities.  The  PMO  will  give 
priority to women (i) for training, and (ii) under the microcredit subcomponent. Training courses will 
be  scheduled  with  special  consideration  to  women’s  availability.  These  courses  will  include 
entrepreneurial  skills  development,  inland  fishery  and  aquaculture  production  and  management 
techniques, simple record and bookkeeping, credit and debt service management, and leadership. 
 
59. 
Gender  awareness  training  will  be  provided  to  NAQDA  staff  at  all  levels.  A  proven  track 
record on gender inclusion in project activities will become a selection criterion for NGOs. NAQDA 
will  fill  its  vacant  positions  by  giving  hiring  preference  to  women.  One  PMO  staff  member  will  be 
designated as the gender focal point responsible for organizing such training, coordinating gender-
related activities, advising on how gender concerns can be incorporated into project activities, and 
monitoring  the  extent  to  which  this  is  done.  Gender-disaggregated  data  will  be  collected  through

60. 
Impact  on  Poverty.  Poverty  reduction  in  rural  areas  of  Sri  Lanka  requires  increasing 
income  by  providing  employment  opportunities  and  improving  consumption.  It  also  means 
stabilizing the economic basis of those living marginally above the poverty line and vulnerable to 
seasonal unemployment or food shortages. Training of CBOs on better resource management will 
improve  productive  capacities  of  rural  communities,  and  transform  fishing  communities  into 
responsible  resource  managers  and  users.  Illegal  fishers  will  be  provided  alternative  income 
through specific fishery-related skills training, which will help prevent illegal fishing. Increased food 
supply  together  with  higher  income  will  improve  nutrition  and  health,  as  will  improved  processing 
facilities using hygienic and sanitary fish-handling practices. As women will be specifically involved 
in these activities, the improvements will have a direct impact on their families and living conditions. 
Targeting  of  specific  subgroups  of  the  population  will  provide  employment  opportunities  in  rural 
areas where these are scarce, and allow these poorer groups to secure an income and establish 
themselves  as  satisfied  members  of  the  communities.  Strengthening  of  CBOs  following  a 
participatory approach will improve their access to services and make them self-reliant and more 
self-confident.  The  number  of  households  below  the  poverty  line  is  expected  to  decline  by  10 
percentage points as a result of project interventions. 
 
C. 

Environment 

61. 
An initial environmental examination conducted during project preparation (a summary is in 
Appendix  10)  showed  that  only  a  few  minor  environmental  impacts  are  likely  as  a  result  of  (i) 
introducing  culture-based  fisheries  in  seasonal  tanks,  (ii)  constructing  water-  and  land-based 
minihatcheries, (iii) undertaking civil works renovate ADCs, (iv) constructing various production and 
marketing  facilities,  and  (v)  using  abandoned  brackish  water  ponds  for  red  tilapia  and  milkfish 
culture.  The  potential  impacts  are  small  and  avoidable,  and  can  be  mitigated  by  other  project 
interventions included in the project costs. None of the proposed interventions is environmentally 
critical or anticipated to create significant adverse or negative impacts on the environment. Instead, 
the Project is likely to bring about benefits in the form of enhanced fisheries management in major 
and medium perennial reservoirs, optimized utilization of the productivity of seasonal tanks, improved 
environmental  sanitation  at  fish-landing  sites,  improved  quality  of  fish  for  human  consumption,  and 
greater public awareness of the need for resource management and environmental protection.  
 
Nevertheless,  environmental  conditions  at  project  sites  will  be  monitored  regularly  to 
62. 
determine changes in levels of essential parameters—mainly those pertaining to water quality—to 
prevent  fish  mortality  or  disease  conditions.  ADCs  will  be  equipped  with  a  basic  chemistry  and 
water  quality  laboratory  where  samples  can  be  brought  from  the  field  for  testing.  Portable  water 
test  kits  will  also  be  procured  to  enable  NAQDA  field  personnel  to  conduct  on-site  water  quality 
monitoring.  Environmental  considerations  have  been  included  in  selection  criteria  (footnote  6)  for 
specific  sites  for  establishing  various  production  and  marketing  facilities,  to  ensure  that  none  of 
these  facilities  is  set  up  in  environmentally  critical  or  protected  areas.  Construction  of  water 
treatment  facilities  and  settling/sedimentation  ponds/tanks  in  brackish  water  ponds  will  be  a 
prerequisite  for  issuing  permits  or  licenses  to  private  fish  farmers,  to  minimize  the  risk  of  water 
quality deterioration in receiving waters. NAQDA, through the PMO, will play an important role in

extension personnel involved in field-level monitoring.

D. 

Risks 

 

63. 
To  minimize  risks  involved  in  implementation,  project  design  incorporates  strengthening 
related  legislation  and  institutions,  within  the  Government’s  policy  of  catalyzing  private  sector 
investment in the subsector, and the Government’s accepted practices for corporate governance. 
Risks associated with the projected increases in production, product marketability and pricing, and 
their  anticipated  impacts  on  fish  consumption  and  affordability  were  considered  during  project 
preparation. Current annual production from inland fisheries and aquaculture is still below the peak 
production achieved in 1990. Keeping in view decadal population growth as well as potential for an 
increase  in  per  capita  consumption,  production  increases  are  expected  to  be  absorbed  by  the 
domestic  markets.  Tilapia  is  consumed  mainly  by  poor  consumers  because  of  its  relatively  low 
price compared with other fish species. Prices of tilapia have remained stable even with increasing  
demand in urban markets, and the risk of prices becoming unaffordable with planned increases in 
production is unlikely. Project design provides for more detailed market surveys and strategies to 
be conducted, and a market information system to be established to support marketing of projected 
surplus production by the private sector. Participatory approaches and social preparation activities 
incorporated in project design will mitigate risks of inappropriate production, and result in expected 
benefits and impacts exceeding the costs.

MARKET, DEMAND, AND SUPPLY ANALYSIS FOR FRESHWATER FISH 
 

Description of the Market 

Market Structure. The main participants in the market for freshwater fish are producers, 
1. 
traders,  and  consumers  who  are  directly  linked  with  the  system.  Large  processors  are  not 
important players at present due to the lack of marketable surpluses at the local markets, i.e., 
within a 10 kilometer (km) radius from the production sites. Any curing or drying of unsold stocks 
is  done  by  the  producers  themselves.  Indirect  participants  are  those  who  provide  support 
services, such as transporters—mostly small vendors who carry the fish short distances to local 
consumers. 
 
Fishers  are  the  first  link  of  the  marketing  chain  as  they  catch  fish  and  make  these 
2. 
available for sale. They are generally small-scale producers who live adjacent to seasonal tanks 
and perennial reservoirs, have low levels of education, and live in very poor conditions. Fishing 
is their major income-generating activity, although supplementary sources such as farming and 
wage  labor  activities  are  also  undertaken,  depending  on  location.  Trading  of  inland  fish  is 
generally undertaken by bicycle and motorcycle vendors, who sell fish door-to-door along their 
regular routes. Bicycle traders, with a daily trading volume of about 50 kilogram (kg), sell fish to 
customers within a 10 km radius, while motorcycle vendors, who on the average trade 75–100 
kg a day, cover about 30 km. Trading largely takes place before noon. The limited trading time 
for  freshwater  fish  is  attributed  to  any  or  a  combination  of  the  following:  (i)  limited  marketable 
surplus,  (ii)  poor  or  inadequate  cold  storage  facilities  (mainly  ice  boxes)  of  traders,  and  (iii) 
limited  trading  capacity  of  traders.  At  present,  consumption  of  inland  or  freshwater  fish  occurs 
mainly around tanks and reservoirs where the fish is readily available. Inland fish, such as tilapia 
which account for 90% of total freshwater fish supply, is easily available in local markets, and is 
popular among poor families due to its affordable price. 
 
Marketing Channels. As the major market segment for freshwater fish is located within 
3. 
the  production  area  itself,  the  principal  marketing  channel  is  sale  to  consumers  by  bicycle 
vendors.  However,  as  demand  for  freshwater  fish  beyond  the  local  markets  has  shown  an 
increasing  trend,  trading  by  motorcycle  has  become  more  popular  due  to  its  efficiency  and 
ability to serve a wider trading area. This has, in turn, resulted in reduced spoilage and better 
quality of fish, and consequently better prices. Truck vendors mainly serve the large reservoirs 
and engage in wholesale trade in identified markets (i.e., weekly fairs and wholesale markets). 
The  narrow  range  of  market  channels  for  freshwater  fish  is  indicative  of  the  currently  limited 
coverage of small fish traders (mainly in the local markets within a 10 km radius from production 
areas)  as  well  as  the  small  volume  of  marketable  surplus  being  channeled  out  of  these 
production areas.

Factors Affecting Demand 

9. 
Income. Time series data are not available to estimate income elasticity of demand for 
fish  in  Sri  Lanka.  However,  studies  in  Bangladesh  (which  is  similar  to  Sri  Lanka  in  fish 
consumption)  indicate  that  income  elasticities  for  different  types  of  fish  (notably  carp)  are 
positive  for  all  income  classes,  and  none  of  the  fish  types  becomes  an  inferior  good  at  the 
highest income quartile.4 Expenditure elasticities of both carp and tilapia were also found to be 
positive in studies in five Asian countries.5 Thus, with the increase in population and per capita 
income, the demand for fish will increase. 
 
10. 
Price.  Freshwater  fish  are  among  the  cheapest  available  in  the  local  market.  The 
farmgate price of tilapia, for example, varies from SLRs20–40 per kg, while its retail price may 
vary  from  SLRs35–55  per  kg.  Compared  with  marine  fish  varieties  (such  as  tuna  and  mullet), 
tilapia prices are lower by as much as 85% and 75%, respectively. Tilapia is even cheaper (by 
20–55%)  than  low-priced  small  marine  fish  varieties.  The  lower  price  at  which  it  is  sold  is, 
therefore,  an  important  factor  in  the  preference  for  freshwater  fish  among  rural  communities 
where incomes are low and poverty incidence is high. 
 
11. 
Availability. Per capita consumption of freshwater fish varies from 0.1–8.8 kg among all 
districts  and  is  observed  to  be  highly  correlated  with  this  commodity’s  availability.  In  districts 
such  as  Anuradhapura,  Moneragala,  and  Polonnaruwa,  where  freshwater  fish  is  commonly 
available  and  where  consumers  have  developed  a  preference  for  freshwater  fish  over  marine 
fish,  per  capita  consumption  of  freshwater  fish  accounts  for  89%,  84%,  and  55%  of  total  per 
capita fish consumption, respectively. Further, as most freshwater fish production is undertaken 
by  rural  communities  in  the  large  reservoirs  (generally  for  home  consumption),  per  capita 
consumption of freshwater fish in rural areas is observed to be higher than consumption levels 
in  urban  areas.  Data  from  the  1985/86  survey  indicate  that  rural  per  capita  consumption  of 
freshwater fish was 1.15 kg, compared with 0.17 kg for urban areas, while for 1996/97, rural per 
capita consumption was estimated at 1.0 kg versus 0.61 kg for urban areas.

16.

export.  Each  of  the  three  markets  is  served  by  a  different  type  of  product.  Fish  for  the  local

milkfish frozen in 5 or 10 kg packs for tuna longline bait.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 

The  United  Nations  ranked  Sri  Lanka  84th  among  174  countries  in  terms  of  human 
1.

reflected in its human development index of 0.73, being by far the highest in South Asia. It ranks 
with  more  economically  advanced  countries  like  Malaysia  and  Thailand  in  terms  of  basic 
indicators  of  human  well-being,  due  to  widespread  access  to  basic  social  services.  Poverty  in 
Sri  Lanka  is,  therefore,  linked  more  to  income  and  consumption  than  to  access  to  basic 
services.  
 
Absolute  poverty  in  Sri  Lanka  is  measured  through  a  food  poverty  line  using  the 
2. 
estimated  cost  per  capita  of  a  basket  of  foodstuffs  that  satisfies  minimum  energy  and  protein 
requirements plus other goods that satisfy minimum nonfood consumption requirements. As this 
“lower poverty line" does not capture the full effects of poverty, 20% is added to it to derive the 
so-called  "higher  poverty  line."  In  Sri  Lanka  about  3.3  million  out  of  17.5  million  people 
(excluding  the  population  of  the  North-Eastern  Province)  were  classified  as  poor  in  1996/97, 
using  the  lower  poverty  line,  while  according  to  the  higher  poverty  line  4.5  million  out  of  17.5 
million people are classified as poor.1 The current national poverty incidence is estimated to be 
about 24%.  
 
3. 
In North-Eastern Province, poverty has a different nature, coexisting with physical injury, 
psychological stress, and war-related trauma. The area has been excluded from official surveys 
during the last 17 years; however, the limited data available suggest that this area is deprived of 
basic  services,  economic  activities  are  hardly  taking  place,  and  close  to  two  thirds  of 
households  are  displaced.  In  the  recently  signed  Poverty  Partnership  Agreement,  the 
Government of Sri Lanka and Asian Development Bank (ADB) agree that little progress can be 
made in reducing poverty in the northern and eastern part of the country until the peace process 
moves forward.

living in rural areas, and distinct regional variations in poverty existing at provincial and district

nonpoor  are  living  marginally  above  subsistence  level  and  thus  highly  vulnerable  to  transitory 
episodes of poverty caused by seasonal unemployment or food shortages. Overall, about 40% 
of the country’s population is either poor or vulnerable to poverty.

Dietary  Imbalance.  The  amount  and  the  sources  of  calorie  intake  in  the  urban,  rural, 
and estate areas vary significantly. The per capita consumption of rice and wheat flour is about 
one third higher in the rural and estate areas than in the urban areas. The proportion of protein

and chicken is almost three times the proportion of animal protein in the rural areas. Sea fish is 
the principal source of protein in all areas, but consumption in urban areas is almost double that 
of rural areas and 10 times that of the estates. Freshwater fish still plays a minor role in urban 
areas. Consumption is higher in the rural areas, but overall restricted due to lack of availability. 
 
Lack of Access to Services. Especially small perennial and seasonal tanks are located 
12. 
in  remote  and  sparsely  populated  areas,  where  access  to  services  is  more  limited. 
Consequently, the incidence of poverty is higher here than around larger perennial tanks. Some 
22% of the total households in the project area do not have latrines and only 58% have access 
to safe drinking water. About 30% of the total households are connected to electricity. However, 
the  nine  districts  have  sufficient  schools  and  an  adequate  number  of  teachers.  Access  to 
extension  services  is  a  major  problem.  Not  only  does  the  extension  staff  lack  skills  and  are 
limited  in  number,  they  are  also  handicapped  by  the  unavailability  of  transport  and  have  no 
incentives to go to these more remote areas.  
 
13. 
Conflicting Interests. The respondents of the project preparatory technical assistance 
(TA)  survey  described  a  variety  of  different  conflicts  related  to  fisheries:  (i)  access  to  water 
between farmers and fishers in areas where water availability is low and irregular; (ii) extension 
staff being biased toward particular political groups and more affluent clients; and (iii) fisherfolk 
having engaged in extremely imbalanced relationships with affluent truck-owning fish vendors, 
particularly in some larger perennial tanks in the south. The dependence between fishers and 
traders is a significant feature of the sector. Traders provide fishing equipment, nets, and boats 
on a credit basis and purchase the produce from the fisher. The relationship between the small 
fisher  and  the  small  bicycle  vendor  is  more  balanced.  But  with  bigger  vendors,  the  fishers 
become  more  disadvantaged,  do  not  get  their  due  share,  and  are  pressured  to  accept  lower 
purchase prices. This has in some communities developed into open confrontation and disrupts 
community life. Ethnicity does not, however, play any role in these conflicts.

1. 
In accordance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) guidelines, an initial environmental

establishment of the interventions and model enterprises, a generic IEE was prepared for each 
intervention regardless of the site for its establishment. The Project is classified as environment

B. 

Description of the Project 

2. 
The Project will promote market-driven and sustainable management of inland fisheries 
and  aquaculture.  The  Project  will  be  largely  implemented  in  the  country’s  dry  zone,  and 
comprises  five  components:  (i)  inland  fisheries  and  aquaculture  development;  (ii)  fish  quality 
improvement  and  marketing,  (iii)  credit,  (iv)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (v)  project 
management. Details of the Project are given in the main text of the report.  
 
C. 

Description of the Environment 

3. 
Physical  and  Ecological  Features.  Climatically,  the  island  is  characterized  by  the 
effects  of  two  monsoons:  the  southwest  monsoon  from  May  to  September  and  the  northeast 
monsoon from October to March. Based on the rainfall pattern, the island is divided into three 
agro-ecological zones: wet, dry, and intermediate. The dry zone comprises over 70% of the land 
area,  receives  less  than  1,000  millimeters  of  annual  rainfall  during  the  northeast  monsoon. 
Average  annual  temperature  in  the  lowlands  from  1961–1990  was  27oC.  Relative  humidity 
varies  from  70%  during  the  daytime  to  90%  in  the  nighttime.  Rainfall  is  the  main  source  of 
freshwater in Sri Lanka.  
 
4. 
Sri  Lanka  has  103  river  basins,  which  cover  a  total  surface  area  of  65,525  square 
kilometers these have 18,387 tanks. The country has about 260,000 hectares (ha) of freshwater 
bodies consisting of about 155,000 ha of small, medium, and large perennial reservoirs; about 
100,000 ha of seasonal tanks; and about 5,000 ha of floodplain lakes. Based on their size and 
fishery  management  norms,  the  reservoirs  are  classified  as  (i)  large  (more  than  800  ha)  and 
medium  (200–800  ha)  reservoirs,  used  for  capture  fishery;  (ii)  small  (1–200  ha)  irrigation 
reservoirs,  used  for  culture-based  fishery;  and  (iii)  seasonal  tanks,  which  hold  water  for  6–8 
months  a  year,  also  used  for  culture  fishery.  The  annual  production  potential  of  these  inland 
water  bodies  has  been  estimated  at  about  60,000  t  from  both  capture  and  culture-based 
fisheries. 
 
5. 
The  actual  number  of  freshwater  fish  species  endemic  to  Sri  Lanka  is  uncertain,  but 
species diversity is low and had to be supplemented through the introduction of exotic species. 
The  most  successful  fish  introduction  in  river  and  reservoir  fisheries  is  the  Oreochromis 
mossambicus (earlier known as Tilapia mossambica), and has been singled out as the species 
responsible for the establishment of a viable reservoir fishery on the island. Within a year of its 
introduction in 1952, O. mossambicus established natural populations in a number of reservoirs, 

  

Appendix 10 

47 

leading to a steep increase in fish yields. Since then, the reservoir fishery, which used to be at a 
subsistence  level,  was  elevated  to  a  commercial  fishery.  Other  cichlids  (tilapia  family)  were 
subsequently introduced, and O. niloticus (a species of tilapia) has performed well in reservoirs. 
The Indian and Chinese major carps have been introduced but have not bred naturally, although 
they  have  been  bred  in  hatcheries.  Two  indigenous  species  of  carp  (Labeo  dussumieri  and 
Puntius sarana) have also been reported in commercial catches from the country’s reservoirs, 
and  other  species,  such  as  Wallago  (a  catfish)  and  Channa  (a  snakehead),  are  found  in  the 
catches in small numbers. 
 
6. 
The  coast  of  Sri  Lanka  is  endowed  with  rich  aquatic  habitats.  About  45  brackish  water 
estuaries and lagoons are spread throughout the coastline with a combined water surface area 
of 158,017 ha, along with about 710 square kilometers of mangrove swamps, mudflats, and salt 
marshes  along  the  coastline,  of  which  35  square  kilometers  have  been  converted  into  prawn 
ponds. At present, P. monodon (jumbo tiger prawn) is the only brackish water species produced 
on  a  commercial  scale  in  the  coastal  areas  of  the  country.  Other  brackish  water  species 
presently  being  grown  in  Sri  Lanka  are  mud  crab  (Scylla  serrata),  oysters  (Crassostrea 
madrasensis),  mussels  (Perna  perna  and  P.  viridis),  and  seaweed  Gracilaria  sp.  The  brine 
shrimp, Artemia salina, has also been cultured in salterns in Palavi  (North Western Province) 
and in Hambantota and Bundala (Southern Province), where the prevailing extreme conditions 
of evaporation and high salinity favor Artemia growth and reproduction.  
 
7. 
Human and Economic Development. The 2001 total population of the eight districts in 
which  most  project  interventions  are  to  be  established  was  about  6.1  million,  with  an  average 
household  size  of  4.4.  Kurunegala  and  Ratnapura  are  the  two  most  populated  districts.  In  the 
inland rural areas, income is generally sourced from agriculture, commerce, or microenterprises. 
The greater percentage of income is sourced from agriculture, and a majority are wage-earning 
agricultural  workers.  They  own  no  land  and  often  have  no  access  to  production  outputs. 
Appendix 9 gives details of socioeconomic conditions in the project area. 
 
8. 
Quality of Life Values. Many of the small perennial and seasonal tanks are situated in 
remote and sparsely populated areas. Consequently, basic infrastructure is limited. Access is a 
problem  because  of  the  absence  of,  or  low-grade,  roads,  and  access  to  safe  drinking  water, 
electricity, and proper sanitation is inadequate. Health services are also limited, but the number 
of schools and teacher is adequate. 
 
9. 
Archeological or Historical Treasures. Anuradhapura has a number of landmarks and 
sites  often  visited  by  tourists.  Polonnaruwa  has  six  archeological  sites,  all  protected  areas.  In 
addition,  the  project  area  has  10  wildlife  reserves  and  four  protected  forests.  Project 
interventions will not be located close to these protected sites. 
 
D. 

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 

10. 
An  initial  screening  of  possible  environmental  impacts  of  project  components  was 
undertaken  at  an  early  stage  of  project  preparation  to  determine  which  components  would 
require further examination. The results indicated that two of the five components needed more 
investigation,  inland  fisheries  and  aquaculture  development,  and  fish  quality  improvement  and 
marketing.  Using  ADB’s  Checklist  of  Environmental  Parameters  for  Fisheries  and  Aquaculture 
Projects,  the  following  prototype  interventions  were  screened  to  segregate  those  parameters 
with  “no  significant  impacts”  from  those  with  significant  adverse  impacts  (small,  moderate,  or 
major): (i) culture-based fisheries in minor reservoirs and seasonal tanks, (ii) water-based mini-
hatcheries, (iii) land-based mini-hatcheries, (iv) red tilapia culture in brackish water ponds, and

inadequate  design  or  operation  and  maintenance.  Nor  were  any  likely  significant  impacts 
identified  based  on  the  critical  environmental  review  criteria  in  the  ADB  checklist.  However, 
most of the prototype interventions could have small or moderate impacts due to site selection 
and/or inadequate design, and small impacts during the construction stage for the small-scale 
infrastructure  development  and  market  establishment.  The  potential  small  and  moderate 
impacts identified (in accordance with the checklist) and recommended mitigation measures are

E. 

Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Program 

14. 
The  interventions  identified  as  having  potential  negative  environmental  impacts  should 
be  monitored,  particularly  those  with  effects  predicted  due  to  site  selection.  Water  quality 
monitoring  should  be  conducted  in  the  perennial  reservoirs  where  water-based  minihatcheries 
are installed, in the seasonal tanks, and in the land-based hatcheries and other culture facilities 
to  be  set  up  by  the  Project.  The  following  essential  water  quality  parameters  should  be 
monitored  regularly:  (i)  pH;  (ii)  dissolved  oxygen;  (iii)  biochemical  oxygen  demand  (BOD);  (iv) 
nutrient  concentration  (nitrates,  nitrites,  ammonia,  phosphates);  (v)  suspended  solids;  and  (vi) 
organochlorines.  In  the  open  waters,  water  samples  should  be  regularly  collected  at  sampling 
sites within the project area, and examined in the laboratory using appropriate equipment. The 
sampling frequency will vary with the type of operation. For example, water quality monitoring in 
land-based  minihatcheries  will  have  to  be  done  more  frequently  than  in  the  water-based 
hatcheries  and  growout  farms.  Analysis  of  water  samples  will  be  done  with  the  use  of  water- 
quality  test  kits  to  be  provided  to  the  ADCs  under  the  Project.  Portable  test  kits  will  also  be 
provided for use by extension staff for routine monitoring of water quality in the minihatcheries to 
be put up by the private sector. Water quality monitoring results should be compared with official 
water  quality  standards  established  by  the  Central  Environment  Authority  as  well  as  with 
international water quality standards set by the World Health Organization. This is necessary to 
determine whether an indicator exceeds maximum allowable levels.

F. 

Findings and Recommendations 

18. 
Only  a  few  minor  environmental  impacts  are  likely  as  a  result  of  factors  related  to  site 
selection  and  construction,  but  these  are  small  and  avoidable  or  mitigable.  In  the  case  of 
construction-related impacts, these are localized and temporary in nature and can be minimized 
through  careful  planning  and  the  adoption  of  proper  construction  practices.  Possible  adverse 
effects  of  red  tilapia  culture  in  unused  or  abandoned  brackish  water  shrimp  ponds  can  be 
mitigated  by  providing  sedimentation  or  settling  ponds  for  drain  water  prior  to  release  into  the 
receiving  waters.  Some  socioeconomic  impacts  may  result  from  project  implementation  in  the 
perennial and seasonal tanks, but these can be minimized by participatory mechanisms and the 
application of conflict resolution techniques under the Project. 
 
19. 
Overall,  therefore,  the  Project  is  not  expected  to  result  in  adverse  environmental 
impacts.  Instead,  it  is  likely  to  bring  about  positive  impacts,  including  (i)  enhanced  fisheries 
management in the major and medium perennial reservoirs, (ii) optimal utilization of the natural 
productivity  of  minor  reservoirs  and  seasonal  tanks,  (iii)  improved  environmental  sanitation  at 
the fish-landing sites, (iv) improved quality of fish for human consumption, and (v) greater public 
awareness of the need for resource management and environmental protection. Nevertheless, it 
is suggested that environmental conditions at project sites be monitored regularly to determine 
changes in the levels of essential environmental parameters that indicate the need for remedial 
or  preventive  measures.  In  addition,  socioeconomic  parameters  need  to  be  monitored, 
particularly as social conflicts could arise as a result of the increased use of seasonal tanks for 
fisheries. 
 
Conclusion 

20. 
Based  on  the  findings  of  the  IEE,  the  preparation  of  an  environmental  impact 
assessment  is  not  required.  However,  environmental  criteria  should  be  included  among  the 
criteria to be used in selecting sites for project interventions. Site selection criteria for the minor 
perennial reservoirs and seasonal tanks should include minimal susceptibility to flooding and the 
presence  of  favorable  water  quality  parameters  (e.g.,  pH  of  7  and  above,  conductivity  of  200 
umhos/centimeters  and  above,  high  transparency,  low  levels  of  suspended  solids,  and 
availability  of  phytoplankton,  particularly  blue-green  and  green  algae).  Also,  the  model 
enterprises  and  production  facilities  to  be  established  under  the  Project  will  not  be  situated  in 
areas within or close to protected or environmentally critical areas, and will follow Government 
requirements in this regard.
